bibl.title: Despatch from Samuel S. Sevier to A. A. Adee, October 26, 1887
Despatches from United States Consuls in Monrovia, 1852-1906

correspAction.roleName: U.S. Second Assistant Secretary of State

div1.p: Monrovia Franklinton Franklin Co. N.C. Oct 26/87
Hon. A. A. Adee Second Asst Secretary of State Washington D. C.
Sir: your favor of the 22nd inst came duly to hand and was glad to hear from you. Please permit me to intrude upon your time by asking you for question in

regard to my account with the State Department as U.S. Vice Consul Genl when I was in Liberia. In the month of July I was at the Department of State and I was told that many of the items which include my report were disallowed. See ch items as for messanger at the Legation and many others. Please allow me to state that I cannot get
vouchers for such items because I am now living in this country and no hopes as far as I know of going back. I have written to the Secretary of State all about the matter of which I hear speaks.
My fourth quarter 1886 in which I paid messenger $15. was disallowed. My first quarter 1887 in which I paid my messenger was also disallowed. Sir permit me to say

I paid the messenger every quarter during my service as U.S. Vice Consul $15.00; but could not get a voucher; because the boy was a native boy who could not write; and further I did not fully that I had to send vouchers for every little sum. I hope the Department will consider these items for messenger charged against me which I have paid. Further more I hope the Department of State
consider that I took the Legation in charge render many disadvantage not being acquainted with the work and its rules.

I am willing that the Department of State disallow the funderal expenses of Moses A. Hopkins; but for the rest which I think is due me should be paid. I paid $44.89 to Mrs. E J. Harmon of Cape Palmas as I was told to do. Please look at one of your

Consular Series and you will find where I was told so to do by the Asst Secretary of State, and that has been charged against me. I have all many items charged against me which I have paid in order to keep up the credit of the U.S. Legation.
The reason G. Moore has many of my drafts is because when I had small returns to pay and had not the money to do it.

with their firm always would advance me the money until I would afford to draw a large draft. I could not draw a draft for every little item; so I got them to pay off what I owed and at the end of each quarter I paid them in draft that is the reason you see such a large draft or amount disallowed. I have written to Secretary of State about these things or facts as named

but I have not heard from him. I want matters all fix up; therefore I again write. Please try and explain matters to the Department of State for me. I do not wish to cheat the government out one cent more than what is due me. I inclose a letter from C. H. Taylor U.S. Minister at Monrovia which I cannot understand toward the last where he speaks of my character through life would be darkened.

Am I indebted to the U.S. Government or is the Government indebted to me? Why should he speak in that way? I don't understand him. I did my best in serving the U.S. government and if I am short I am willing to forego what little the government is indebted to me. I know the Department of State will do what is best. Out side of the funeral expenses of the late Minister Moses A.

Hopkins I hope the Department will disallow nothing. Indeed I had trouble in Africa in dowing what I did do for the government, after Hopkins death. Please sir, just think of my situation at that time where not being acquainted with such a position. Hoping to hear from you soon.
I remain dear sir your obedient servant
Samuel S. Sevier
Franklinton N.C.
Monrovia Liberia September 14, 1887
Rev. S. S. Sevier

SirL I have to inform you in obedience to instruction No. 4, Consular series, recieved from Washington dated June 7th 1887, in answer to your No 68 of April 19th., that the Department refuses to interfere in any agreement between you and Mr. Hopkins, during his life time for services rendered by you to him. Using the language of the Department I have to say "Mr Hopkins was paid in full for the term of his service and Mr Sevier must look to the estate of Mr Hopkins for payment of his claim if he means to press it."

Letters received here, on the 13th instruct, informer you, that your draft of April 26th 1887, for $17.55 drawn against salary account is disallowed on account of the insufficiency of the appropriations to pay nonresidents. This information is received from the office of the comptroller of the currency washington D. C. and carries date June 23rd 1887. I am also instructed to inform you by the Department of states No 5 consular series of date July 11th rec'd in Monrovia on the 13th that on the 3rd quarter of 1886 your account is approved for $94.57 instead of for $127.07 as claimed by you the following items being disallowed. Cleaning Legation $10.00 attending Minister Hopkins $1.50 Hiring book 8 creed to take Minister Hopkins to steamer $6.00 suspended for want of voucher $15.00 for messanger services. Special account for
& c of late minister Hopkins 5.85 approved for $70.85 stems llowed Professional service and $25.00 Preucliring funeral Roberts $50.00
ourth Quarter 1886 246.95 Approved for $136.29 disallowed:- Payment to servants services in packing re. 8.00 shipping and reshipping efforts $57.66 Messenger wages for $15.00 want of voucher.

First Quarter of 1887 for rent approved for $87.50 for services rendered to vessel Consular agent at Cape Palmas $44.89 is referred for examination to the fifth auditor. Voucher of bill rendered for services re., son $30.00 is not understood be passed on until explained did not tell me of having received Bruce of Accra in reference to hotographer. There are a number of which you were guilty, while the U.S. Government, that need you would not have your character blackened. I am sir rc.
Chas H. J. Taylor
